Sexual dysfunction in a male.question: Entirely explained by lack of adequate stimulation

no.question: Due to the physiological effects of a general medical condition (e.g., vascular disease)
no.yes: Sexual dysfunction caused by a general medical condition

no.question: Due to the physiological effects of a substance (including medication)

yes.question: Sexual dysfunction symptoms predominate in the clinical picture and are sufficiently severe to warrant clinical attention
yes.no: SUBSTANCE INTOXICATION; SUBSTANCE WITHDRAWAL; OTHER ADVERSE EFFECT OF MEDICATION

no.question: Better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., Major Depressive Disorder)
no.yes: Mental Disorder diagnosis (no additional sexual dysfunction diagnosis necessary)

no.question: Better explained as a consequence of severe relationship distress
Deficient sexual or erotic thoughts or fantasies and desire for sexual activity, lasting at least 6 months and causing clinically significant distress

yes.question: Occurring in the context of a "desire discrepancy" in which the man has lower desire for sexual activity than his partner

no.question: Marked difficulty obtaining or maintaining an erection during sexual activity, lasting at least 6 months and causing clinically significant distress
Ejaculation during partnered sexual activity within 1 minute following penetration and before the individual wishes it, lasting at least 6 months and causing clinically significant distress
Marked delay in ejaculation or marked infrequency or absence of ejaculation lasting at least 6 months and causing clinically significant distress
Clinically significant sexual dysfunction not covered above that represents a biological or psychological dysfunction in the individual

yes.question: Occurring in response to a psychosocial stressor
yes.no: OTHER SPECIFIED SEXUAL DYSFUNCTION; UNSPECIFIED SEXUAL DYSFUNCTION
